fields.description:
Steps to reproduce 

1) Log into node1 of a confluence cluster which has 2 or more nodes.
2) Disable daily confluence backups
3) Log into node2 and check their daily backup configuration. 

You will notice that it is still enabled. 

Confluence nodes appear to pickup this setting from the {{confluence.cfg.xml}} file in their home directory. Thus this setting is not stored in the database (like the other settings). 
Changing the setting for daily backups does not propagate to other nodes, thus users that have disabled in one node mistakingly believe that  . 

Confluence Admin's need to disable the issue in every node in order to disable on all nodes
fields.summary: Disabling daily Backups on one node in a cluster does not reflect on other nodes in the cluster

fields.description:
Space Logos are currently stored in the home directory and accessed throughout Confluence using the ResourceManager.  The ResourceManager is not widely used and therefore causes various problems to occur around Space Logos.  If we changed the Space Logo to be stored as an attachment to the Space Description, we could avoid these bugs, and deprecate the ResourceManager.

This storage/display mechanism would mirror that used for User Icons, simplifying the system as a whole.

fields.description:
1. The Tanuki Wrapper is quite a great product (according to our experience)
2. Even a great product need to be tested and configured properly... what Atlassian is normally doing, but not this time ;-)

It seems that the wrapperwin32.conf is wrong. Please check the following:
* wrapper.java.library.path.1 should be set to "..\lib" not to "..\common\lib" otherwise the file wrapper.dll can not be found --> this may cause problems like shutting down Confluence due to misinterpretation of system signals (this is the reason for the Blocker priority, our 2.8 Confluence installation stopped three times in 24 hours) / or alternatively copy wrapper.dll to "..\common\lib"
* I believe that in a productive environment wrapper.debug should be set to FALSE, otherwise the log file will be filled up with many information, that are not very useful for the normal user.
fields.summary: Check wrapper configuration

fields.description:
In the current implementation of page ordering for Confluence 2.8, we use the tree view to move the pages --- both when viewing all pages in the "Browse Space" view and when adding/editing a page.

*Improvement request:* 
Improve usability of page-ordering for large document spaces and accessibility.

*One possible solution* (but there are others) :
Instead of using the tree view, we could allow the user to choose a preceding page from a drop-down box, or some other type of "page picker" functionality. We'd also need to allow then to choose the parent page and parent space. We could offer this as an alternative, for example in add/edit page mode.

Reasons:
* For spaces with large numbers of pages (such as the [DOC|http://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/listpages-dirview.action?key=doc] space on CAC) it is very very cumbersome to move a page. It took me five minutes to move a page from near the bottom to under the "Confluence 2.8 Release Notes". The nodes in the page tree insisted on opening one by one, and the scrolling was very slow.
* We should also consider a solution which is more accessible for people who have problems using a mouse.
fields.summary: Improve usability of page tree for moving and ordering pages

fields.description:
At the moment the installers ability to integrate as a service means that it has to ship with some software called JavaWrapper. This makes the configuration of Confluence way more complex than before, because now we have to ways of configuring settings. This is especially annoying since people who are used to configuring Java Apps and App Servers will have to learn a new way of changing settings, where the old one is perfectly fine (and complicated enough to learn).

We should either get rid of this service thing (which seems overkill for an evaluation, and too complicated to many normal business users anyway), or make sure our documentation is updated, which will be very difficult to make easy to understand. Take this page for example: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Fix+%27Out+of+Memory%27+errors+by+increasing+available+memory  - it now has two options: On windows do this, on Mac do that.  You would need at least two more cases, and also link to the JavaWrapper software for further docs - not exactly easy.

Also, we need a decision whether the installer should be an "Evaluation Installer" for now. My gut feeling tells me that people will run the installer on the desktop box, never shut it down again and make it run as a production server, which it is not. There needs to be a clear statement that it is fine to do so for a couple of days, but if you buy and use it you need to pass it on to the IT guys department.

We might see a big increase in installer issues that will eat up what we have gained in the first place.
fields.summary: Drop services and JavaWrapper from installer, or fix documentation

fields.description:
Any user with permission to edit pages in a space can move attachments in that space to *any* page in Confluence.

Eg: suppose we have a user named StandardUser who has permission to edit pages in GeneralSpace, but no permission to view or edit RestrictedSpace, which contains a page predictably named Home.
StandardUser:
* goes to the attachments view of a page with attachments in GeneralSpace.
* clicks edit.
* types "RestrictedSpace:Home" into the Page field and clicks save.

The attachment is moved.

The user should really need the following permissions:
View Space for RestrictedSpace
Create Attachment for RestrictedSpace
Furthermore, the user should not be restricted from viewing or editing the target page by any page level restrictions.
fields.summary: Users can move attachments to a space they have no permission for

fields.description:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Using+the+RSS+Feed+Builder

The doc is a bit unclear in general and could do with a cleanup. Specifically it needs to clarify:

* A feed can either be anonymous or authenticated
* If your server does not allow anonymous access, only authenticated feeds are offered
* If your server allows anonymous access, the "feed permission" section will appear
* If a feed is anonymous, you only get anonymously-viewable content in the feed regardless of whether you're a user or not

Ref: http://twitter.com/ZAThomas/statuses/789161053
fields.summary: RSS feed builder documentation does not cover feed authentication

Steps to reproduce. 

1) Install a standalone copy of confluence. Set the context to be "/confluence" so you access the local instance as "http://localhost:8080/confluence". 

Now suppose the customer has setup a Web server such as Apache that accesses this server using the URL "http://my.confluence.com", thus has no context. (You don't need to setup Apache to reproduce this, simply keep following the below steps.

2) Change you Server base URL to be "http://my.confluence.com"

3) Export a space (which has attachments, one of which is an image attachment and is displayed on the page) in html format. You will find that the image attachment is located within the export in both export/confluence/download/attachment/.../.../image.jpg and export/download/attachment/.../../image.jpg. 

To reproduce this behaviour more easily I have included a space export. 
After completing step 1,2 above, do the following. 
a) Import the export into your 2.7.3 install. 
b) export the space as a html file. 


Customers should be able to have two different contexts and still not have a duplicate files in the export.
fields.summary: Setting Server Base Url to have a different context causes HTML exports to store two files for the one image attachment.

fields.description:
Important for 
* Release management --- documentation matches Confluence version.
* Internationalisation support in the docs (CONF-10758).
* Customers using offline versions of our documentation.

We need two mechanisms:
*1) Control of page-level destinations:* Externalise the link paths, so that partners, customers and tech writers can control the destination (at page level) of each help link.
*2) Release management:* The Confluence documentation applies to a specific release of Confluence. The DOC space is always for the latest release. Other archive spaces apply to specific previous releases e.g. CONF27, CONF26, etc. The help links need to be redirected to the correct version-specific space.


Suggested solutions --- applied to our other products:
* Solution for (1) above is a help-paths.properties file shipped with the product. Already in use for JIRA, Crowd, FishEye, Crucible
* Solution for (2) above is some sort of redirect mechanism, as we have already done for Crowd and FishEye --- use a {{.htaccess}} file on the {{docs.atlassian.com}} server. 

See blog post: http://blogs.atlassian.com/news/2007/12/using_a_wiki_fo.html

The release management is becoming more and more important as the look and feel of Confluence changes. See attached screenshot showing the sort of problem people are having.
fields.summary: Confluence help links should point to the appropriate version of the docs

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-11413].
  {panel}

I went to a roadshow for Salesforce.com yesterday and one of the features of their product was a document management solution they have called "Content".

One feature they had which I would find useful was the ability to subscribe to individual attachments si that you were notified whenever a change was made.

Now I know that you can create a custom feed for a page to be notified whenever an attachment is changed but if a page had 10 attachments I may only want to know about changes to 2 of them.

For example, there is a page on EAC which the PST uses to attach all files relating to our webinars. Say Boots looks after the slides for the Confluence webinar. I download the file on Monday and subscribe to the attachment. Boots updates the file on Tuesday. I get a notification that the file has been updated so I can then download the latest version.

Not sure how much work is involved in this but I think it would be a great feature to have to boost our sales pitch of using Confluence to replace your shared network drive or document management system.
fields.summary: Add ability for users to subscribe or watch to individual attachment updates

fields.description: When we import a site backup, we use our ResettableHiLoGenerator to reset the ids generated, but we only perform this on the node that imported the backup. This leads the other nodes with an id generation strategy that can lead to primary key conflicts.

fields.description:
When using Confluence, and Tomcat 5.5.26 or Tomcat 6 some users may find that their logins are not remembered.  This is because of a bug in Tomcat's cookie handling.  This is logged against the Atlassian Seraph library used by Confluence as SER-117. SER-117 has been fixed, so we "just" need to use a later version of Seraph.

Note that this only affects Tomcat users; Resin and Orion are not appear to be affected.
fields.summary: Some users' logins are not remembered using Tomcat

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-11406].
  {panel}

*Current functionality*

Currently when you navigate by labels you can add or remove additional labels to your selection. When you select a label the results that are returned provide "Related Labels". Selecting the first additional related label filters the results further. Beyond a combination selection "X+Y" related labels is not as effective as it could be.

For example access the [label for macro|http://confluence.atlassian.com/label/DOC/macro] in Confluence Documentation space
Now select the label ["plugin"|http://confluence.atlassian.com/label/DOC/macro+plugin].
Results are further refined; macro+plugin.

Now select "column" resulting in [macro+plugin+column|http://confluence.atlassian.com/label/DOC/macro+plugin+column]
No results are returned.

*Consider enhancing the UI/navigational element of the labels by providing better "filtering" of labels.*

For example, after making the [macro+plugin|http://confluence.atlassian.com/label/DOC/macro+plugin] selection, the resulting "related labels" would only contain labels that are being utilized on the results for macro+plugin.

The resulting effect is that the user would be able to "drill down" and further refine their set of results from the label results page. This kind of filtering mechanism would be very powerful for navigating and locating information.

Thanks for the consideration.
fields.summary: Navigating Pages by Labels - Label set filters on usage

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-11401].
  {panel}

The linking-feature should support a create-somewhere feature.

e.g. i've got a page "application" in which i've a link referring to a specific server. If this serverpage doesn't exist a page is created as a child of the application, instead of beeing a child of "Server".

it could look like [websrv:parent=Server]

I know that the {link-page} macro already provides this, but this macro is not supported by the {incoming-links} macro, so i think it's easier to extend the standard link-plugin.

fields.description: It would be great instead of having to navigate to a Page's Info page to simply have an option on the 'Tools' drop-down menu of a page to copy the page's Tiny Link to your clipboard. Please see the screenshot attached.
